Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as a step towards totalitarian governance, contrary to democratic principles.
The bill is perceived as damaging to free speech, which is considered a non-negotiable human right.
The definition of 'misinformation' in the bill is viewed as subjective, particularly concerning what constitutes 'harm'.
The government is seen as incapable of policing subjective interpretations of harm.
There is a perception of increasing restrictions on free speech in Australia over recent years.
Notable Quotes: This proposed legislation is another step towards totalitarian governance that is so opposite of a free democracy.
Free speech is a non-negotiable human right and must be safeguarded.
It is simply not possible for governments to police such subjectivity.
